newsitem.title: DUBAI: Iran dismisses report of link to Saudi blast.
newsitem.headline: Iran dismisses report of link to Saudi blast.

text.p: Iran on Saturday dismissed as "lies" a U.S. newspaper report that one of its officials was involved in the bombing of a U.S. military compound in Saudi Arabia last year.
The move came two days after a U.S. official said his country has not concluded that Iran was behind the truck bombing that killed 19 U.S. servicemen but will take action if it does.

"This is not the first time that America embarks on telling lies about the Islamic Republic of Iran," the Iranian News Agency IRNA quoted Major General Mohsen Rezaei, Commander of Iran's Revolutionary Guards, as saying.
"Usually after such an incident, American and Zionist officials and media try to attribute the incident to the Islamic Republic of Iran without producing any evidence."
The Washington Post said last week an Iranian official was linked to the blast.

The newspaper quoted U.S. and Saudi officials as saying Brigadier Ahmad Sherifi, a senior Iranian intelligence officer, met two years before the blast with Hani Abd Rahim Sayegh, a Saudi Shi'ite arrested in Canada last month as "a direct participant" in the June 25 bombing.
It said U.S. officials disagreed whether the link was strong enough to require U.S. retaliation against Iran.
